header.title: Grimoire - Manuskript um 1775: Ein okkultes Ritual der Schwarzen Magie
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Grimoire Tradition, Black Magic

central_thesis: The book presents a transcription and facsimile of an 18th-century manuscript detailing an occult devil-ritual for summoning rebellious spirits, specifically Lucifuge Rofocale, to gain access to the 'treasures of the underworld'. It is presented as a significant historical document of black magic, predating the first dated printed editions of the 'Grand Grimoire' from which it is fragmentarily derived.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the manuscript, highlighting its origin around 1775 and its content as an occult devil-ritual for engaging with rebellious spirits, particularly Lucifuge Rofocale, to unlock the treasures of the underworld. It contextualizes the manuscript as a fragment of the 'Grand Grimoire' or 'Der wahrhaftige feurige Drache' but notably older than the first dated printed versions. It also mentions the manuscript's inclusion of alchemical and herbal healing recipes (not depicted in this edition). A strong warning is issued against practicing the ritual, explicitly stating that 'who makes sacrifices, makes himself a perpetrator!' and disclaiming liability for any resulting harm.

This part of the book presents the original handwritten pages of the manuscript side-by-side with a literal transcription. The transcription faithfully reproduces the original spelling and grammatical peculiarities of the 18th-century German text, offering scholars and practitioners a direct view of the source material.

This chapter provides a modernized transcription of the ritual text, making it more accessible and understandable for contemporary readers while closely adhering to the original meaning and content. This section clarifies the instructions and invocations for those studying the text.

This section lists various historical and modern editions of works related to the 'Grand Grimoire', 'Sechstes und Siebentes Buch Mosis', and other grimoires or texts on Black Magic, providing academic context and further reading for researchers interested in the lineage and parallels of this manuscript's content.

key_concepts.definition: The central document of the book, an 18th-century handwritten manuscript outlining a specific ritual of black magic.
The core operational procedure described in the manuscript, focused on summoning and interacting with infernal entities.
The category of occult practice to which the ritual belongs, characterized by engaging 'rebellious spirits' for worldly gain, such as accessing hidden treasures.
Identified as the 'Premierminister Luzifers' (Prime Minister of Lucifer), whose 'signature' is crucial for obtaining the 'key to the treasures of the underworld' through the described ritual.

key_concepts.term: Adonay, Elohim, Ariel, Jehova, Tagla, Mathon
key_concepts.definition: Powerful divine and angelic names (often from Hebrew/Qabalistic traditions) used in invocations and prayers within the ritual to command or appeal to spirits, characteristic of Solomonic grimoires.

The operator or 'master' who conducts the ritual, performs the invocations, and interacts with the summoned spirits. The term implies a position of authority and responsibility within the magical operation.

A specific magical ring, to be made from the skin of a sacrificed goat, engraved with symbols (A, a, j, Jesus between crosses), and worn by the Karsist. It serves as a protective and commanding tool within the magical circle.
A bloodstone to be acquired and carried by the Karsist. It functions as a protective amulet against malevolent spiritual influences during the ritual.
A sacrifice, specifically a young goat, whose blood and ashes are utilized in specific phases of the ritual to honor and propitiate the invoked entities.

A hazelnut rod, of specific dimensions (19 Zoll and 12 Linien) and condition (never having borne nuts), that must not be broken prematurely. It is a critical tool of command and authority in the ritual, channeling the Karsist's will.

practical_system.description: The system outlined is a classical Solomonic-style grimoire operation focused on the summoning of infernal entities (specifically Lucifuge Rofocale and his subordinates) for material gain, namely access to 'treasures of the underworld'. It mandates extensive preparatory rites, stringent purification, the creation and use of specific magical tools, animal sacrifice, powerful invocations utilizing divine names, and direct interaction with the summoned spirit.
tools: Hazelnut Rod (19 Zoll, 12 Linien, from a tree that never bore nuts)
4 Nails from a child's coffin (cut from a tree)
Gold or Silver (as an offering to the spirit)
rituals: **Phase 1: Preparation & Purity (Beginning on the First Quarter Moon):** Observe strict abstinence from women. Acquire a hazelnut rod (19 Zoll, 12 Linien in length) from a tree that has never borne nuts; it must not be broken before the following sunrise. Obtain an 'Ematill' (bloodstone) and carry it continuously for protection. Locate a secluded, private site for the ritual.

**Phase 2: The Sacrifice (Third Day):** Purchase a young goat. Fashion a collar of 'Verbena' (ironwort) for the goat. Bring the goat to the ritual site. The Karsist must have their right arm bare to the armpit, holding a steel knife. Ignite a fire using bright wood. Offer a prayer to Adonay, Elohim, Ariel, and Jehova, asking them to accept the sacrifice with honor and pride. Cut the goat's throat, skin it, and burn its flesh entirely to ashes. Gather the ashes and cast them towards the sun, invoking the aforementioned divine names, expressly rejecting the blood for their honor and power, and requesting their acceptance of the ashes. Preserve the goat's skin for the 'Kabbalistic Ring'.

**Phase 3: The Kabbalistic Ring & Circle:** Using the goat's skin, create a ring. Fasten it with four nails obtained from a child's coffin (specifically, nails from a coffin cut from a tree). Engrave the ring with the symbols: 'A', 'a', 'j', and the name 'Jesus' placed between two crosses (refer to provided image). Draw a magical circle as depicted in the manuscript. The Karsist and their 'comrades' enter this circle. Position two candles and two verbena wreaths to the right and left of the ring, then light the candles. Prepare a new vessel for the Karsist, filling it with coals from willow wood burned on the day the ritual lights were first kindled. Add brandy, blessed incense, and camphor, creating an 'eternal fire' within the vessel.

**Phase 4: Invocations & Spirit Contact:** Perform the following sequence of invocations:
    1. **First Prayer (Offering):** Offer incense and coals to Adonay, dedicating one's entire soul, addressing 'o großer Adonay, Elohim, Ariel und Jehova'.
    2. **Second Prayer (Supplication):** Petition Adonay, thanking for creation, asking for grace, and preventing 'rebellious spirits' from possessing divine treasures.
    3. **First Call to the Devil (Kaiser Luzifer):** Command Luzifer to appear 'without noise and without foul odor' using the names of the eternal God (Father, Son, Holy Spirit), threatening to compel him with the power of Adonay, Elohim, Ariel, Jehova, Tagla, Mathon. The command 'Venite, venite Submiritillor Luzifuge' is stated.
    4. **Second Call (Forceful Command):** Reiterate the command to Luzifer to leave his dwelling within a quarter-hour, threatening to send Astaroth if he does not appear or speak. Further threat to strike him and his family with the 'terrible rod' using a litany of powerful names including Adonay, Elohim, Ariel, Jehova, Tagla, Mathon, Almouzin, Arios, Pithona, Magots, Sylphae, Gabots, Salamandrae, Gnomus, Terrae, Coelis, Godens, Aqua. 
    Upon the spirit's appearance, the Karsist must carry the Kabbalistic Ring, and all other participants must remain silent. The spirit will verbally acknowledge the Karsist's 'book' and promise to appear when called for needs. The Karsist offers the 'Great Gabalisse Ring' (Kabbalistic Ring) and speaks 'Rofo Gal'. The spirit (identified as Lucifuge Rofocale) promises wealth (a first piece of gold/silver) on condition of the Karsist's mercy and eternal secrecy regarding the operation.

critical_analysis.relevance: This manuscript is a historically valuable document within the Western Esoteric and Grimoire traditions, particularly for its relationship to the 'Grand Grimoire' and similar Solomonic-derived texts. Its earlier dating (circa 1775) compared to most printed editions offers crucial insight into the transmission and evolution of such magical operations in popular occultism. The text outlines a systematic approach to 'black magic' focused on spirit communication for material gain, typical of its era, emphasizing rigorous preparation, ritual purity, specific tools, and potent invocations using divine names to command infernal entities. The editor's explicit warning, while highlighting the perceived danger, also underscores the serious nature in which such texts were (and still are) regarded by practitioners and scholars.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience for this book includes academic scholars and historians of Western Esotericism, occultists deeply interested in the historical development of grimoire traditions and Solomonic magic, and collectors of rare occult texts. Due to the explicit warnings regarding the dangers and ethical implications of the described ritual, it is decidedly not intended for casual or inexperienced practitioners seeking to perform these operations, but rather for scholarly study and contextual understanding of historical magical practices.
